awd_abstract_narration:
California faces a shortage in qualified Science, Technology, Engineering and Math/Career and Technical Education (STEM/CTE) instructors who have the work experience, proficiency in academic subject areas, and pedagogical knowledge to effectively prepare high school and community college students for careers. With 32 trade and technical schools and 28 community colleges offering CTE programs in the San Francisco Bay Area alone, the need for well-prepared CTE teachers in this region is enormous. To meet the workforce needs of the science- and technology-focused economy of the San Francisco Bay Area, it is critical that CTE teacher preparation efforts include a commitment to increasing the pool of qualified STEM teachers at the secondary and community college level. The City College of San Francisco's "Growing CTE/STEM Teachers" project aims to ensure that clear pathways exist for future STEM/CTE teachers at the high school and community college levels. These pathways will include resources, support, information, courses, and partnerships with employers. The project will focus on those priority or emerging industry sectors identified by the California Community Colleges Chancellors Office. These include: advanced manufacturing; advanced transportation and renewables; agriculture, water and environmental technologies; energy efficiency and utilities; ICT/digital media; and life sciences/biotechnology. 

This project will carry out four primary activities in pursuit of its goal of increasing the pool of qualified STEM teachers at the secondary and community college level. First, the project team will engage in outreach to recruit high school students, community college students, and individuals already in the workforce into CTE/STEM teacher preparation pathways. Second, the principal investigators (PIs) will provide student support services to increase persistence and completion rates. Third, the PIs will provide technical assistance and professional development to other colleges in the region and statewide and serve as a clearinghouse for technical assistance and professional development, especially in the area of CTE/STEM teacher preparation. Finally, the project will advocate for CTE/STEM teacher preparation as a vital part of the statewide infrastructure supporting STEM-based CTE industries.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Growing CTE/STEM Teachers

NSF/ATE #1801099

P/I Kathleen White, City College of San Francisco, Teacher Prep

Co P/I Maura Devlin Clancy, City College of San Francisco, MakerSpace

Eva Schiorring, Evaluator

California, is experiencing crippling shortages of teachers.  The crisis is particularly dire in subjects most critical to building a competitive workforce: STEM and CTE. Growing CTE/STEM Teachers was launched in 2018 to respond to the crisis.  

The project’s intellectual merit is an innovative approach to recruiting and preparing diverse CTE/STEM teachers. For decades, California’s teacher recruitment projects and funds sought to identify and support CTE/STEM teaching candidates in their final years of college. This strategy is not effective.

Targeting students in high school and early in their college careers, the project pairs City College of San Francisco’s Teacher Prep Programs (TPP) hands-on approach to teacher education with the College’s new and NSF-supported MakerSpace curriculum.  Students’ interest in teaching is stimulated as they experiment in Maker courses, apply STEM and CTE skills and knowledge to build and innovate, and work alongside teachers in classrooms where they have a direct impact on improving learning opportunities for younger students in their own neighborhoods.  Hands-on experiences are supported with classroom content on teaching pedagogy, offered within the context that teaching is social justice in action  The project intentionally recruited diverse groups of students including African American, Latino/a students, women, Asian Pacific Islanders and students with limited STEM success and included high school students in dual-enrollment pathways and community college students who may not "see" themselves as CTE/STEM teachers.

The PI and Co-PI led regional initiatives to (i) grow and diversify the CA Bay Area’s teaching workforce; (ii) increase awareness of and support for teacher recruitment and preparation; and (iii) utilize MakerSpaces as an entry point for STEM instruction.  During the project period, Teach for the Bay, led by the PI, became a major force in networking the region’s teacher preparation programs and leveraging additional support for teacher education, including through innovative apprenticeship programs.  Outcomes included:

  • Development of a Maker Studies program certificate and five courses including MAKR 33 specifically for teachers - 228 students

  • Fieldwork and work experiences courses in classrooms - 720 students 

  • Child Development and Education pedagogy courses -1,354 students 

  • Counseling, advising and career and employment workshops - 1146 students

  • Free, virtual conferences open to the San Francisco Bay region for community college and high school students interested in teaching careers:

  • Teach for the Bay #1- October 5-9, 2021 - 2774 enrollments 

  • Teach for the Bay #2 - October 6-8, 2021 - 1500 enrollments 

  • Conference Presentations on the Role of Making and Makerspaces in Education:Nation of Makers, NACCE/ MakeShift, MIRA, NSF/ATE/PI, BA MakerFaire, CSU Making, ISAM
  • Conference Presentations onTeacher Preparation: NCATE, ACCCTEP, TPP, CCCAOE, CAN, BACCC    

 Publications/Awards: 

  • Community College and High School Career Technical Education (CTE) Shortages in the SF BAY Region;  July 2020

  • ATE Project Summary; September 2021

  • Received “Pitch for the Trades” award, NACCE and the Ratcliffe Foundation Award

COVID significantly impacted project from midpoint to end. All activities moved online. No courses were cancelled and Maker kits were mailed to students homes. Strategies to teach lab concepts in a distance education format were developed.

Evaluation findings were used to make adjustments in implementation; document progress toward outcomes; and gather evidence to test the viability of the project’s alternative approach to growing a diverse CTE/STEM teaching workforce.  Findings included:

  • Consistent increases in students’ interest in teaching/working with young people after completing education courses with classroom field experience.  In 2021, for example, 12% of 133 participants in the summer classroom fieldwork course reported an increased interest in teaching after taking the course. The surveys also found that among all participants black and brown students experienced the greatest increases. These results are consistent with findings from surveys and focus groups conducted by the evaluator during all three years of the project. 
  • High level of engagement in the MAKR courses developed with NSF support. Interviews with the PI and CO-PI found continuous efforts to strengthen, innovate and adapt when COVID moved the courses online. 
  • The Teach for the Bay website and conference was monitored by the evaluator and were effective.The PI's established the “Teaching is Social Justice in Action” framework.

Survey and interview findings consistently found evidence supporting the project’s alternative approach to teacher recruitment.  Students provided with the opportunity to work in classrooms and community-based programs became more interested in teaching and open to working with young people. MAKR courses showed the potential to engage students in innovating and building - and in thinking about teaching others to do so. 

Overall, the evaluation findings indicate that the integration of early field work in education,  Makerspace experiences, and new ways to teach education theory and approaches combine to create an innovative and alternative path to recruiting and growing a diverse teaching workforce.


Last Modified: 11/03/2021
Modified by: Kathleen White
